--- title: "Data types and classes" subtitle: "Lecture 9" date: "2025-09-23" format: revealjs: output-file: 09-data-types-classes-slides.html footer: "[ðŸ”— sta199-f25.github.io](https://sta199-f25.github.io/)" theme: slides.scss transition: fade slide-number: true logo: images/logo.png pdf-separate-fragments: true toc: false html: code-link: true filters: - remove-fmt-skip.lua --- # Warm-up ## While you wait: Participate ðŸ“±ðŸ’» {.xsmall} ::: columns ::: {.column width="70%"} ::: wooclap Fill in the blanks: I'm a `_____` (first-year, sophomore, junior, senior) and on Tuesdays I have `_____` class(es). ::: ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} ![](images/wooclap-qr.png){width="200" fig-align="center"} ::: small Scan the QR code or go to [app.wooclap.com/sta199](https://app.wooclap.com/sta199). Log in with your Duke NetID. ::: ::: ::: ## Announcements {.smaller} - Survey: Confidence in STEM courses at Duke - Exam 1: - In class on Thu, Oct 2 - Take home Thu, Oct 2 after class until Sat, Oct 4 at noon - Covers lectures 1-10, labs 1-4, and homeworks 1-3 - Practice exam to be posted on Friday, exam review on Tue, Sep 30 # Data types ## How many classes do you have on Tuesdays? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} survey ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 Ã— 2 tue_classes year 1 2 2 Sophomore 3 three First-year 4 1 Senior ``` ::: ::: ## Variable types ::: question What type of variable is `tue_classes`? ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} survey ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 Ã— 2 tue_classes year 1 2 2 Sophomore 3 three First-year 4 1 Senior ``` ::: ::: ## Let's (attempt to) clean it up... {.scrollable} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} survey <- survey |> mutate( tue_classes = case_when( tue_classes == "three" ~ "3", # add more conditions as needed .default = tue_classes ), tue_classes = as.numeric(tue_classes) ) survey ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 Ã— 2 tue_classes year 1 NA 2 2 Sophomore 3 3 First-year 4 1 Senior ``` ::: ::: # Data types ## Data types in R - **logical** - **double** - **integer** - **character** - and some more, but we won't be focusing on those ## Logical & character ::::: columns ::: column **logical** - Boolean values `TRUE` and `FALSE`
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} typeof(TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "logical" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column .fragment} **character** - character strings

::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} typeof("First-year") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "character" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::::: ## Double & integer ::::: columns ::: column **double** - floating point numerical values (default numerical type)
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} typeof(2.5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "double" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} typeof(3) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "double" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column .fragment} **integer** - integer numerical values (indicated with an `L`)
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} typeof(3L) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "integer" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} typeof(1:3) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "integer" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::::: ## Concatenation {.smaller} Vectors can be constructed using the `c()` function. - Numeric vector: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} c(1, 2, 3) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 2 3 ``` ::: ::: . . . - Character vector: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} c("Hello", "World!") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Hello" "World!" ``` ::: ::: . . . - Vector made of vectors: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} c(c("hi", "hello"), c("bye", "jello")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "hi" "hello" "bye" "jello" ``` ::: ::: ## Converting between types ::: hand with intention... ::: ::::: columns ::: column ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- 1:3 x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 2 3 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} typeof(x) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "integer" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column .fragment} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} y <- as.character(x) y ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "1" "2" "3" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} typeof(y) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "character" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::::: ## Converting between types ::: hand with intention... ::: ::::: columns ::: column ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- c(TRUE, FALSE) x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] TRUE FALSE ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} typeof(x) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "logical" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column .fragment} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} y <- as.numeric(x) y ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 0 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} typeof(y) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "double" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::::: ## Converting between types ::: hand without intention... ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} c(2, "Just this one!") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "2" "Just this one!" ``` ::: ::: . . . R will happily convert between various types without complaint when different types of data are concatenated in a vector, and that's not always a great thing! ## Converting between types ::: hand without intention... ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} c(FALSE, 3L) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0 3 ``` ::: ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} c(FALSE, 1.2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0.0 1.2 ``` ::: ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} c(2L, "two") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "2" "two" ``` ::: ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} c(TRUE, "two") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "TRUE" "two" ``` ::: ::: ## Participate ðŸ“±ðŸ’» ::: columns ::: {.column width="70%"} ::: wooclap What is the output of `typeof(c(1.2, 3L))`? ::: wooclap-choices - `"character"` - `"double"` - `"integer"` - `"logical"` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} ![](images/wooclap-qr.png){width="200" fig-align="center"} ::: small Scan the QR code or go to [app.wooclap.com/sta199](https://app.wooclap.com/sta199). Log in with your Duke NetID. ::: ::: ::: ## Explicit vs. implicit coercion ::::: columns ::: column **Explicit coercion:** When you call a function like `as.logical()`, `as.numeric()`, `as.integer()`, `as.double()`, or `as.character()`. ::: ::: {.column .fragment} **Implicit coercion:** Happens when you use a vector in a specific context that expects a certain type of vector. ::: ::::: # Data classes ## Data classes {.smaller} ::: incremental - Vectors are like Lego building blocks - We stick them together to build more complicated constructs, e.g. *representations of data* - The **class** attribute relates to the S3 class of an object which determines its behaviour - You don't need to worry about what S3 classes really mean, but you can read more about it [here](https://adv-r.hadley.nz/s3.html#s3-classes) if you're curious - Examples: factors, dates, and data frames ::: ## Factors {.smaller} R uses factors to handle categorical variables, variables that have a fixed and known set of possible values ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} class_years <- factor( c( "First-year", "Sophomore", "Sophomore", "Senior", "Junior" ) ) class_years ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] First-year Sophomore Sophomore Senior Junior Levels: First-year Junior Senior Sophomore ``` ::: ::: ::::: columns ::: {.column .fragment} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} typeof(class_years) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "integer" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column .fragment} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} class(class_years) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "factor" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::::: ## More on factors We can think of factors like character (level labels) and an integer (level numbers) glued together ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} glimpse(class_years) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Factor w/ 4 levels "First-year","Junior",..: 1 4 4 3 2 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} as.integer(class_years) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 4 4 3 2 ``` ::: ::: ## Dates ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} today <- as.Date("2025-09-23") today ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "2025-09-23" ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} typeof(today) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "double" ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} class(today) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Date" ``` ::: ::: ## More on dates We can think of dates like an integer (the number of days since the origin, 1 Jan 1970) and an integer (the origin) glued together ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} as.integer(today) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 20354 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} as.integer(today) / 365 # roughly 55 yrs ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 55.76438 ``` ::: ::: ## Data frames We can think of data frames like like vectors of equal length glued together ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df <- data.frame(x = 1:2, y = 3:4) df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` x y 1 1 3 2 2 4 ``` ::: ::: ::::: columns ::: column ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} typeof(df) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "list" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: column ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} class(df) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "data.frame" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::::: ## Lists {.smaller} Lists are a generic vector container; vectors of any type can go in them ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|2|3|4"} l <- list( x = 1:4, y = c("hi", "hello", "jello"), z = c(TRUE, FALSE) ) l ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $x [1] 1 2 3 4 $y [1] "hi" "hello" "jello" $z [1] TRUE FALSE ``` ::: ::: ## Lists and data frames {.smaller} - A data frame is a special list containing vectors of equal length ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` x y 1 1 3 2 2 4 ``` ::: ::: - When we use the `pull()` function, we extract a vector from the data frame ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df |> pull(y) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 3 4 ``` ::: ::: # Working with factors ## Read data in as character strings ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} survey ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 Ã— 2 tue_classes year 1 NA 2 2 Sophomore 3 3 First-year 4 1 Senior ``` ::: ::: ## But coerce when plotting ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(survey, mapping = aes(x = year)) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-data-types-classes_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-38-1.png){width=100%} ::: ::: ## Use forcats to reorder levels {.smaller} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} survey |> mutate( year = fct_relevel(year, "First-year", "Sophomore", "Junior", "Senior") ) |> ggplot(mapping = aes(x = year)) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: There was 1 warning in `mutate()`. â„¹ In argument: `year = fct_relevel(year, "First-year", "Sophomore", "Junior", "Senior")`. Caused by warning: ! 1 unknown level in `f`: Junior ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-data-types-classes_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-39-1.png){width=100%} ::: ::: ## A peek into forcats {.smaller} ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%" .fragment} Reordering levels by: - `fct_relevel()`: hand - `fct_infreq()`: frequency - `fct_reorder()`: sorting along another variable - `fct_rev()`: reversing ... ::: ::: {.column width="50%" .fragment} Changing level values by: - `fct_lump()`: lumping uncommon levels together into "other" - `fct_other()`: manually replacing some levels with "other" ... ::: :::

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
